hin.faq_generator_a1_text: The Generator is a tool to help users to reproduce data from d-portal in other webpages/blogs.
hin.faq_generator_a2_text: To help users who want to display their own data, or data they are interested in, within their own website/blog.
hin.faq_generator_a3_text:
Make selections from the dropdown menus and C&P the code provided into your webpage’s html.

For more information see http://www.d-portal.org/news/2014-11-30-Interactive-IATI-data-d-portal-generator.html
hin.faq_generator_a4_text: It’s dynamic, so will update automatically overnight. If you change your data, this will be reflected. So when you’ve got content from the generator in your site or blog post, it will change accordingly!
hin.faq_generator_a5_text:
The embedded data in your blog post / website will stay up as long as the d-portal site is up (eg permanently).

The only time this can go wrong is if your website provider disallows you to include external widgets in your blog posts, ie. if you can embed a youtube video into your blog post, you can embed generator content in your post.
hin.faq_generator_a6_text:
Both secured and non-secured HTTP access is enabled and supported on d-portal. This should let users on secured domains use Generator content.

Use https://d-portal.org/ctrack.html#view=generator instead.

If you are unsure if this affects you, see if your company's website uses https:// instead of http:// in the website address.
hin.faq_generator_q4_text: How often will the generated content on my webpage update?
hin.faq_generator_q6_text: Help! I'm trying to create the widget in my company's internal website but it's not working.
hin.faq_paragraph1_text: डी-पोर्टल एक विशाल साइट है कि न केवल देश और प्रकाशक आधारित पोर्टल लेकिन यह भी savi, जेनरेटर, पानी का छींटा और जल्द ही, खोज जैसे उपकरण शामिल है - एक सरल खोज dstore और अतारांकित इस के साथ द्वारा समर्थित इंटरफ़ेस के बारे में सवालों की एक से बढ़ डेटाबेस आता है वास्तुकला और साइट के विभिन्न भागों की कार्यक्षमता।
hin.faq_paragraph2_text: जनरल, तकनीकी और जेनरेटर के बारे में सवाल - अभी के लिए, हम सवालों के 3 अलग अलग प्रकार के नीचे इन तोड़ने। भविष्य में, हम सूची में और अधिक टैब जोड़ने होगा आगामी सुविधाओं के लिए क्षतिपूर्ति करने के लिए। हम वर्तमान में अंग्रेजी और फ्रेंच दोनों अनुवादों का समर्थन करते हैं। अगर आप अन्य भाषाओं के लिए अनुवाद प्रदान करना चाहते हैं, तो हम आपको संपर्क में आने के लिए प्रोत्साहित करते हैं ।
hin.faq_paragraph3_text: पूछे जाने वाले प्रश्न http://www.d-portal.org/faq.html पर पाया जा सकता है।
hin.faq_technical_a11_text: These pages for individual activities come from IATI Registry.
hin.faq_technical_a13_text:
Additional data is stored in Github, including
  • list of funder Org IDs
  • currencies
  • exchange rates
  • sector codes
  • CRS data
hin.faq_technical_a14_text: Newly published files are updated every night and then once a week, a full re-import of all files is done. The re-import ensures that any external value that may have been changed; for example, exchange rates, will be applied to all relevant data.
hin.faq_technical_a15_text: An activity which includes part of 2024 according to the activity’s start and end dates.
hin.faq_technical_a16_text: Some organisations only produce data with 3 digit codes. We convert the 5 digit codes to 3 digits to unify the data for visualisation on d-portal.
hin.faq_technical_a17_text: Google charts have deprecated these graphs - some country graphs are showing up as empty even when there is data in them. Bar charts allow users to see the data in relation to each other.
hin.faq_technical_a18_text: We're only showing graphs that have been published using the same currency. We've kept SAVi (Simple Activity Viewer) as simple as possible so there are no extra calculations made on the page, just displaying the raw xml as we get them.
hin.faq_technical_a19_text:
The transactions are merged if they are published for the same date.

The last transaction will stretch across the lifetime of the activity.
hin.faq_technical_a1_text:
‘Expenditure’ and ‘Disbursements’ for Spend columns/data. If there are neither, but ‘Outgoing Commitment’ data exists, then the Outgoing Commitment data will be shown.

'Outgoing commitment' for Total commitment columns. If outgoing commitments have not been published, but Disbursement and Expenditure exist, then the sum of Disbursement and Expenditure will be shown.

‘Budgets’ in activity file, for Budget columns/data (eg in tables on d-portal) - if no budget data is present in the activity file, then ‘planned-disbursements’ are used if present.
hin.faq_technical_a20_text: We display machine-readable data where possible (ie. when we have codelists for those elements), narratives within these elements will not be displayed.
hin.faq_technical_a2_text:
• If a transaction date is not present, d-portal uses the transaction-value date in order to ascertain the date of a transaction (and therefore assign it to a specific year).
  • Only displaying countries that exist in ISO3166 Alpha-2.
  • Removing secondary organisations - flagged as secondary sources in IATI Registry - from tables (to avoid double counting, eg secondary organisations are for example UN-OCHA who re-publish data which would replicate data from those organisations in the same table - see here for list of secondary organisations excluded in these instances).
  • Not displaying organisations with 0 datasets in the IATI Registry.
  • If there are neither Expenditure nor Disbursement data but Commitment data does exist then the Commitment data will be displayed.
  • In order to match against CRS data in tables, government departments are combined and shown under the country name - details of which departments are in Github.
  • There are currently plans under consideration to use the lowest hierarchy level data only, should data at multiple hierarchies exist, in order to avoid double counting.
hin.faq_technical_a3_text:
Using the transaction value date/transaction date (eg in Spend columns in tables).

Using the end date in the budget data (eg in Budget columns in tables).
hin.faq_technical_a4_text:
Anything with invalid date ranges (eg start date after the end date).

Projects with invalid date ranges that cannot be placed in one of the other 3 categories (Active, Planned, Ended).
hin.faq_technical_a5_text:
• Default USD

    Currently (please note this may change soon) converting to USD using the exchange rate of the date specified in the value-date attribute. So when we display USD, it is very accurate to that date.

  • Other currencies

    For other currencies, the USD value is just converted using today’s exchange rate (please note this may change soon).

  • For budget information in future?

    Using the latest exchange rates (International Monetary Fund) every night and doing a full re-import once a week, so future budgets will use the current exchange rates and should be updated weekly.
hin.faq_technical_a6_text:
For charts - need a transaction with transaction date in the relevant year (the latest complete year, eg currently 2024) with a valid recipient country code or valid sector code, depending on which chart it is.

For tables - as above, with transaction date relating to the relevant year column in the table.

For maps - any transactions (from any year) with valid location tag and recipient country code (to be valid it needs to be on the relevant IATI codelists).
hin.faq_technical_a8_text:
Activity start/end dates are used to work out which projects are active or ended or planned for the future.
  • Active projects are projects with a start date in the past and with an end date in the future.
  • Ended projects are projects with an end date in the past.
  • Planned projects are anything with a start date in the future.
hin.faq_technical_a9_text: Using ‘location’ tags within the data to plot projects on the maps - either lat/long or point/pos, depending on which the organisation uses.

hin.faq_technical_q17_text: For the country and sector graphs on the acitivity pages, why have your changed them into bars?
hin.faq_technical_q18_text: Why are some graphs missing for some types of transactions on the acitivity pages?
hin.faq_technical_q19_text: Why are there less nodules on some of the graphs for transactions on the activity pages?
hin.faq_technical_q1_text: Which transaction types are used/not used in d-portal?
hin.faq_technical_q20_text: Why are some data not showing up on the activity pages when they are available in the XML?
hin.faq_technical_q2_text: How / where is the data tidied up before being displayed in d-portal?
hin.faq_technical_q3_text: How is data apportioned to a specific year?

hin.feedback_paragraph1_text: नमस्कार , और डी पोर्टल के रूप में हाथ लिए बीटा परीक्षकों लेने के लिए आप सभी को धन्यवाद . हम किसी भी और सभी प्रतिक्रिया का स्वागत करते हैं , सुझाव और वेबसाइट के बारे में हो सकता है आप चिंताओं को इतना नीचे टिप्पणी के रूप में उन्हें ' पोस्ट करने के लिए स्वतंत्र महसूस कृपया . कुल मिलाकर, हम विशेष रूप से प्रस्तुत किया जा रहा है जो डेटा को समझने के संदर्भ में , स्पष्टता और उपयोगकर्ता अनुभव पर ध्यान केंद्रित करना चाहते हैं .
hin.feedback_paragraph2_text: ऐसा करने के लिए समय देने के लिए बहुत बहुत धन्यवाद ! हम उपयोगी और आसानी से तैनाती कुछ , संगठनों रिपोर्टिंग से बेहतर गुणवत्ता वाले डेटा , सबसे महत्वपूर्ण उद्देश्य को बढ़ावा देने के लिए एक दिलचस्प चर्चा का विषय बनाने की उम्मीद है .
hin.footer10_text: यदि आपके पास डी-पोर्टल में डेटा कैसे दिखाया गया है, या डेटा की तारीख तक कैसे हो, के बारे में आपके कोई प्रश्न हैं, तो कृपया सामान्य प्रश्न देखें या आईएटीआई सहायता हेल्पडेस्क से संपर्क करें

hin.footer8_text: यह देश से या विकास गतिविधियों और बजट IATI को प्रकाशित पर प्रकाशक द्वारा जानकारी प्रदान करता है।
hin.footer9_text: इस समय हम लोग बीटा में हैं। जबकि डी-पोर्टल सार्वजनिक रूप से उपलब्ध है, यह समाप्त नहीं माना जाता है। आप कीड़े और याद आ रही सुविधाओं का अनुभव हो सकता है, लेकिन यही वजह है कि हम आपकी प्रतिक्रिया और समर्थन की जरूरत है।
hin.gen_paragraph1_text: वहाँ IATI भीतर रोचक जानकारी और स्वतंत्र रूप से अन्य वेबसाइटों और ब्लॉगों पर इसके बारे में काटने के आकार के टुकड़े साझा करने के लिए सक्षम होने में महत्वपूर्ण मूल्य की एक बड़ी राशि है। डी-पोर्टल जनरेटर उपयोगकर्ताओं d-portal से विशेष जानकारी चयन करें और इसे सीधे एम्बेड कोड को अपनी वेबसाइट में करने के लिए अनुमति देता है।
hin.gen_paragraph2_text: एक बार जब आप किसी भी सामग्री एम्बेडेड है यह स्वचालित रूप से (रात) को अद्यतन करेगा के रूप में 'प्रकाशकों डेटा IATI रजिस्ट्री में अद्यतन किया जाता है। उन सामग्री पर क्लिक करें जब वे डी-पोर्टल पर प्रासंगिक पृष्ठ के लिए निर्देशित किया जाएगा ताकि वे आगे की जांच कर सकते हैं।

hin.github_info2_text: d-portal.org वर्तमान में विकसित और चीजें लगातार बदल रहे हैं इसलिए तैयार किया जा रहा है. हमें अपने सुझाव, बग रिपोर्ट और मुद्दों या संपर्क support@iatistandard.org भेजें
hin.github_info3_text: आप d-portal पर खबर के साथ तारीख तक रखने के लिए करना चाहते हैं गूगल समूह की सदस्यता कृपया.
hin.index_paragraph1_text: संसाधन प्रवाह को ट्रैक करता है एक देश के आधार पर जानकारी मंच है . यह विकास गतिविधियों का निर्धारण और निगरानी के साथ सहायता कर सकते हैं कि जानकारी के साथ मंत्रालयों , सांसदों और सिविल सोसायटी को प्रदान करने के उद्देश्य से है .
hin.index_paragraph2_text: पहली यात्रा में आईसीटी यह अंतरराष्ट्रीय सहायता पारदर्शिता पहल (IATI) और साथ ही ओईसीडी डैक ऋणदाता रिपोर्टिंग प्रणाली द्वारा प्रकाशित एकत्रित (2012) सबसे हाल के डेटा के माध्यम से प्रकाशित मौजूदा डेटा शामिल हैं. भविष्य के विकास , अन्य बातों के साथ सहायता सूचना प्रबंधन प्रणाली , राष्ट्रीय बजट से डेटा और तुलनीय सामाजिक - आर्थिक संकेतकों की एक श्रृंखला शामिल होंगे .
hin.index_paragraph3_text: लटकती मेनू में डाटा दिलवाया नए डेटा के साथ हर रोज जीएमटी 0 जो अद्यतन डाटाबेस से बनाया गया है IATI रजिस्ट्री से.
hin.index_paragraph4_text: हम ISO3166-2 का उपयोग प्रकाशकों द्वारा सूचित कर रहे हैं कि देश की सूची. रोपण और डेटा स्रोतों के लिए लिंक, लिए यहां जाने .
hin.index_paragraph5_text: उनके IATI प्रकाशक आईडी के साथ प्रकाशकों की सूची सीधे IATI रजिस्ट्री डेटाबेस से आता है.
hin.index_paragraph6_text: प्रकाशक की लटकती सूची इन प्रकाशकों द्वारा रिपोर्ट प्रकाशित एक्सएमएल गतिविधियों से आता है.
hin.install_info_text: अपनी वेबसाइट के लिए विगेट्स बना.
hin.install_paragraph1_text: d-portal परियोजना के दिल में किसी को भी कहीं भी, डी पोर्टल के पीछे खुला स्रोत कोड लेने के लिए खुद के लिए यह तैनाती और उनके हितों की कि किसी भी देश के लिए एक स्वनिर्धारित डी पोर्टल बना सकता है कि लक्ष्य है. यह सहायता सूचना प्रबंधन प्रणाली, राष्ट्रीय बजट और तुलनीय सामाजिक - आर्थिक संकेतकों की एक सीमा से किसी अन्य डेटा जोड़ने शामिल हो सकते हैं.

jpn.about_paragraph10_text: DIは2014年8月の終わりに開発や準備の現在のステージに資金を提供している。あなたは、d-portalの進行中の開発の資金の一部に興味がある場合 お問い合わせください support@iatistandard.org
jpn.about_paragraph11_text: オープンソースの概念は、他の人が参加すると一緒に、より良いプラットフォームを構築します期待して共有リソースに依存しています。これは、発見したバグを報告し、あなたが持っているのプラットフォームのようにしたい新機能を貢献するか、他の人がそれを使用できるようにしても、新しいテーマを作成することを含みます。
jpn.about_paragraph12_text: d-portalに基づいて、他のサイトでは、以下に一覧表示されます。 イメージを追加するsupport@iatistandard.orgでお問い合わせください。
jpn.about_paragraph14_text: 1。資源はどこから来るのか？2。彼らは（部門と場所によって）どこに行くのですか？
jpn.about_paragraph15_text: 最近の現在および将来のデータが提示され、データ・ソース間で比較されています。
jpn.about_paragraph1_text: d-portal.orgは、あなたが国別またはIATIに公開された開発活動や予算上の発行者による情報を提供することにより、IATIデータを探索するのに役立ちます。
jpn.about_paragraph2_text: これは、企画·開発活動の監視を支援できる情報を関係省庁、国会議員と市民社会を提供することを目的とする。
jpn.about_paragraph3_text: その最初の反復では、国際援助の透明性イニシアティブ（ IATI ）だけでなく、が発行する最新の（ 2012年）のデータを通じて発行した最新のデータが含まれていますOECD DAC Creditor Reporting System。
jpn.about_paragraph4_text: 現在のプラットフォームには、二つの質問を提起：どこのリソースから来るのか、そしてどこに（部門や場所によって）行くのですか？最近の現在および将来のデータが提示されたデータソース間で比較されている。
jpn.about_paragraph5_text: 国の観点からこれらの質問に答えるためには、単に利用可能なデータを表示するには不十分である：それは、情報のギャップをプロットすることも同様に重要である。品質不良または欠落したデータに対処することは、情報インターフェースの重要な部分です。
jpn.about_paragraph6_text: オープンソースのプラットフォームです。これは、あなたが自由にソースコードを使用して、独自のポータルを構築するためのプラットフォームのすべての側面を使用できることを意味します。
jpn.about_paragraph7_text: それが現在、どの国のための一般的な展開を提供しますが、それは、地域のニーズを満たすために、国のカスタマイズされて、特定の意図を持って開発されました。あなたが特定の国のためにカスタマイズされたバージョンを作成することができます方法の詳細については、インストールする方法を参照してください。
jpn.about_paragraph9_text: 2014年4月にメキシコでグローバル·パートナーシップ会議に2013年12月から走ったD- portal.orgの初期開発はによって資金を供給された IATI と Development Initiatives (DI)
jpn.alert1_text: d-portal.org はアルファリリース中旬4月に予定され、非常に初期のまだ開発中です。あなたの忍耐をありがとう！すべてのフィードバックを提供してください

jpn.dash_paragraph1_text: Dashは、主に出版社の統計に焦点を当て、それらによって報告されたデータの質とd-portal.orgを移入するデータの概要である。
jpn.dash_paragraph2_text: 無効なデータが報告されたときに、どこを示すことによって、Dashは、メインのサイトに反映されているギャップを説明することができるようになります。
jpn.dash_paragraph3_text: Dashは、国固有のものではありませんので、すべての国全体で利用可能な出版社のすべての統計情報がポータルに含まれて閲覧することができます。これは、複数の被援助国での活動を報告し、複数の出版社が存在するという事実に対応するためにある。
jpn.dash_paragraph4_text: Dash現在の位置はアクセスできますかhttp://d-portal.org/ctrack.html?#view=dash。 Dashは、新しい機能であり、まだ開発されています。
jpn.develop_info_text: 私たちは, GitHubのにしている。
jpn.discover_paragraph1_text: Explore 重い現在開発中の新機能です。 dstoreに裏打ちされたとQ、それは、ユーザーが膨大なIATIのデータベースを介してフィルタリングするためのシンプルな検索インターフェイスを提供します。
jpn.discover_paragraph2_text: 我々は現在、Exploreの直観とユーザビリティに関するフィードバックを求めています。ご希望の場合は、やってみると Githubのフォーラムにして新しい問題を追加することによって、私達にあなたのフィードバックを送信したりでください、 support@iatistandard.orgを介して連絡を取ります。私たちは、あなたが何を考えて聞いてみたいです！
jpn.discover_paragraph3_text: Explore で試してみてください Search http://www.d-portal.org/ctrack.html#view=search
jpn.dlogs_paragraph1_text: 夜間のインポートから生成されたd-portalデータベースの統計とグラフ。 これは、dポータルに公開されているIATI活動の増加を追跡するために作成されたものです。
jpn.dlogs_paragraph2_text: https://xriss.github.io/D-Portal-Logs/のデータベースにアクセスしてください。
jpn.dquery_paragraph1_text: 完全なデータベースへの読み取り専用のSQLインターフェイスであるdqueryは、技術ユーザーがすべてのIATIデータへのアクセスを提供し、dポータルとXML、JSON、HTMLおよびCSV形式でデータをダウンロードするオプションを提供します。
jpn.dquery_paragraph2_text: この新機能はまだテストおよび更新されています。 質問や提案がある場合はご連絡ください。
jpn.dquery_paragraph3_text: http://www.d-portal.org/dquery のインターフェイスを使用します
jpn.dstore_paragraph_text: dstoreは、リアルタイムクエリでの使用に最適化nodejs + PostgreSQL + SQLiteバージョンでIATIデータストアを助成。
jpn.explore_paragraph1_text: 以下にそれらのデータを探索するために、国や出版社を選択してください。
jpn.explore_paragraph2_text: だけの国と​​IATIに公開されたデータと出版社が探査のための利用可能です。
jpn.faq_explore_a1_text:
EXPLORE is made up of two parts – a series of filters, and a freetext box.

1. Filters

These are a selection of filters relating to the IATI Standard allowing users to choose and refine the IATI data they want to explore.

2. Freetext

This is a freetext box allowing users to search for themes and topics, and specific activities published to IATI.
jpn.faq_explore_a2_text: The EXPLORE feature is on the front page of d-portal.org and helps users find activities published to the IATI Standard based on keywords - it was originally developed to help people who wanted to find information on specific humanitarian crises.
jpn.faq_explore_a3_text:
Select multiple filters from across the dropdowns. As you build a query using these filters the space underneath the filters will populate with an indication of how many activities are available to view based on your selections.

You can then click ‘Explore Results’ to find out more about those activities.
jpn.faq_explore_a4_text:
Recipient Country and Publisher

The organisations that have published to the IATI Standard, and the countries where funds have gone to as published within IATI data.

Sector Group and Sector

The numeric codes and names to describe sectors within the OECD DAC CRS, as used within the IATI Standard.

Activity Status

The numeric codes and names within the IATI activity status field.

Year Range

Years from 1960 to ‘present year + 2’.

More filters

The numeric codes and names within the IATI activity status field. Click on Glossary to find out more about individual filters.
jpn.faq_explore_a5_text:
Type in one or more keywords and press enter to see how many activities have been found.

Click ‘Explore Results’ to see lists, graphs and maps allowing further exploration of the data.

Refine your search by adding multiple words – e.g. ‘Hurricane Matthew’ will find more refined (fewer) results than ‘Hurricane’.
jpn.faq_explore_a6_text: Clicking ‘Explore Results’ provides results in the usual d-portal format (stats and charts which you can explore by clicking through to tables).
jpn.faq_explore_a7_text: This searches the Title and Description fields within all published IATI activities.
jpn.faq_explore_a8_text: EXPLORE is adapted for English plural nouns - e.g. typing ‘Refugee’ will include results for ‘Refugees’.
jpn.faq_explore_a9_text: The COVID-19 button follows the IATI Publishing Guidance. It currently searches the database for COVID-19 in title and description fields and looks for the relevant codes in the humanitarian-scope element.

jpn.faq_general_a13_text:
Data that is marked as invalid IATI xml when using the Validator.

Mismatch between ‘Identifier’ in publisher’s profile in the IATI Registry, and reporting-org in that publisher’s data – this will show zeroes in the publisher’s data until the two are matched.

Transaction type code not present.

Not using either Disbursements or Expenditure in transaction type field.

Country and Sector graphs are displayed by adding up Transaction type codes 3 (Disbursement) and 4 (Expenditure) so activities without transactions or the right transaction type codes will not have these graphs.

Dates in incorrect format in the data.

Activities without end date are not shown on the list of projects ending soon or any lists that need an end date to order them.

The map section will not be shown if there are no activities with longitude and latitude data.

Illogical dates such as activity end date before activity start date.

No data relevant to the year being viewed on a pie chart or table (eg where a pie chart shows 2024 data and data published only relates to 2023).

If updating your Registry profile only, changes will show after the weekly full import (each weekend) as d-portal only updates nightly the data that has been changed in the xml.
jpn.faq_general_a1_text: A view of all IATI (International Aid Transparency Initiative) data by recipient country or publisher, comparable with latest OECD DAC CRS (Creditor Reporting System) data.
jpn.faq_general_a2_text: IATI and CRS data (see below for more information).
jpn.faq_general_a3_text: The International Aid Transparency Initiative - IATI is a voluntary, multi-stakeholder initiative that seeks to improve the transparency of aid, development, and humanitarian resources in order to increase their effectiveness in tackling poverty.
jpn.faq_general_a4_text: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development’s Development Assistance Committee Creditor Reporting System - which contains Official Development Assistance data.
jpn.faq_general_a5_text:
The IATI data comes from the IATI Registry.

The CRS data comes from CRS tables and stored on Github.
jpn.faq_general_a6_text:
Publishers report their IATI data at varying degrees of detail, and data is updated and improved all the time by publishers. If a publisher only publishes data for 2023, it won’t appear in 2024 columns/charts etc.

d-portal attempts to only reflect what is in the data and does not make corrections to data or information published to IATI, with only small exceptions to make the site user-friendly*

See also information about data quality (Afghanistan used as example)
jpn.faq_general_a7_text:
Zeroes may denote issues with data quality (eg codes, dates, etc which are incompatible with the IATI Standard). There will shortly be links to the publisher’s page on the IATI dashboard to investigate specific data quality issues.

Dashes show that that donor/organisation is not currently an IATI publisher.
jpn.faq_general_a8_text:
IATI data is updated every night (importing any data which has changed from the previous day) and a full import is done each weekend - in each instance the data is pulled from the IATI Registry.

CRS data is downloaded annually when it becomes available and then stored in Github.

jpn.faq_generator_a1_text: The Generator is a tool to help users to reproduce data from d-portal in other webpages/blogs.
jpn.faq_generator_a2_text: To help users who want to display their own data, or data they are interested in, within their own website/blog.
jpn.faq_generator_a3_text:
Make selections from the dropdown menus and C&P the code provided into your webpage’s html.

For more information see http://www.d-portal.org/news/2014-11-30-Interactive-IATI-data-d-portal-generator.html
jpn.faq_generator_a4_text: It’s dynamic, so will update automatically overnight. If you change your data, this will be reflected. So when you’ve got content from the generator in your site or blog post, it will change accordingly!
jpn.faq_generator_a5_text:
The embedded data in your blog post / website will stay up as long as the d-portal site is up (eg permanently).

The only time this can go wrong is if your website provider disallows you to include external widgets in your blog posts, ie. if you can embed a youtube video into your blog post, you can embed generator content in your post.
jpn.faq_generator_a6_text:
Both secured and non-secured HTTP access is enabled and supported on d-portal. This should let users on secured domains use Generator content.

Use https://d-portal.org/ctrack.html#view=generator instead.

If you are unsure if this affects you, see if your company's website uses https:// instead of http:// in the website address.
jpn.faq_generator_q4_text: How often will the generated content on my webpage update?
jpn.faq_generator_q6_text: Help! I'm trying to create the widget in my company's internal website but it's not working.
jpn.faq_paragraph1_text: d-portalはサビ、発電機、ダッシュとすぐに、検索のような国や出版社だけでなく、ベースのポータルだけでなく、ツールが含まれています広大な敷地である - これによりdstoreとQに裏打ちされたシンプルな検索インターフェイスは、についての質問の成長データベースが来ますサイトの異なる部分のアーキテクチャと機能。
jpn.faq_paragraph2_text: 一般的な、技術的およびジェネレータについての質問 - 今のところ、我々は質問の異なる3種類までこれらを破ります。今後は、今後の機能を補うために、リストに複数のタブを追加していく予定です。 現在、英語とフランス語の両方の翻訳をサポートしています。 他の言語の翻訳をご希望の場合は、連絡してください。
jpn.faq_paragraph3_text: よくある質問は http://www.d-portal.org/faq.html から見つけることができます。
jpn.faq_technical_a11_text: These pages for individual activities come from IATI Registry.
jpn.faq_technical_a13_text:
Additional data is stored in Github, including
  • list of funder Org IDs
  • currencies
  • exchange rates
  • sector codes
  • CRS data
jpn.faq_technical_a14_text: Newly published files are updated every night, as well as a full re-import of all files. The re-import ensures that any external value that may have been changed; for example, exchange rates, will be applied to all relevant data.
jpn.faq_technical_a15_text: An activity which includes part of 2024 according to the activity’s start and end dates.
jpn.faq_technical_a16_text: Some publishers only produce data with 3 digit codes. We convert the 5 digit codes to 3 digits to unify the data for visualisation on d-portal.
jpn.faq_technical_a17_text: Google charts have deprecated these graphs - some country graphs are showing up as empty even when there is data in them. Bar charts allow users to see the data in relation to each other.
jpn.faq_technical_a18_text: We're only showing graphs that have been published using the same currency. We've kept SAVi (Simple Activity Viewer) as simple as possible so there are no extra calculations made on the page, just displaying the raw xml as we get them.
jpn.faq_technical_a19_text:
The transactions are merged if they are published for the same date.

The last transaction will stretch across the lifetime of the activity.
jpn.faq_technical_a1_text:
‘Expenditure’ and ‘Disbursements’ for Spend columns/data. If there are neither, but ‘Outgoing Commitment’ data exists, then the Outgoing Commitment data will be shown.

'Outgoing commitment' for Total commitment columns. If outgoing commitments have not been published, but Disbursement and Expenditure exist, then the sum of Disbursement and Expenditure will be shown.

‘Budgets’ in activity file, for Budget columns/data (eg in tables on d-portal) - if no budget data is present in the activity file, then ‘planned-disbursements’ are used if present.
jpn.faq_technical_a20_text: We display machine-readable data where possible (ie. when we have codelists for those elements), narratives within these elements will not be displayed.
jpn.faq_technical_a2_text:
• If a transaction date is not present, d-portal uses the transaction-value date in order to ascertain the date of a transaction (and therefore assign it to a specific year).
  • Only displaying countries that exist in ISO3166 Alpha-2.
  • Removing secondary publishers - flagged as secondary sources in IATI Registry - from tables (to avoid double counting, eg secondary publishers are for example UN-OCHA who re-publish data which would replicate data from those publishers in the same table - see here for list of secondary publishers excluded in these instances).
  • Not displaying publishers with 0 datasets in the IATI Registry.
  • If there are neither Expenditure nor Disbursement data but Commitment data does exist then the Commitment data will be displayed.
  • In order to match against CRS data in tables, government departments are combined and shown under the country name - details of which departments are in Github.
  • There are currently plans under consideration to use the lowest hierarchy level data only, should data at multiple hierarchies exist, in order to avoid double counting.
jpn.faq_technical_a3_text:
Using the transaction value date/transaction date (eg in Spend columns in tables).

Using the end date in the budget data (eg in Budget columns in tables).
jpn.faq_technical_a4_text:
Anything with invalid date ranges (eg start date after the end date).

Projects with invalid date ranges that cannot be placed in one of the other 3 categories (Active, Planned, Ended).
jpn.faq_technical_a5_text:
• Default USD

    Currently (please note this may change soon) converting to USD using the exchange rate of the date specified in the value-date attribute. So when we display USD, it is very accurate to that date.

  • Other currencies

    For other currencies, the USD value is just converted using today’s exchange rate (please note this may change soon).

  • For budget information in future?

    Using the latest exchange rates (International Monetary Fund) every night and doing a full re-import once a week, so future budgets will use the current exchange rates and should be updated weekly.
jpn.faq_technical_a6_text:
For charts - need a transaction with transaction date in the relevant year (the latest complete year, eg currently 2024) with a valid recipient country code or valid sector code, depending on which chart it is.

For tables - as above, with transaction date relating to the relevant year column in the table.

For maps - any transactions (from any year) with valid location tag and recipient country code (to be valid it needs to be on the relevant IATI codelists).
jpn.faq_technical_a8_text:
Activity start/end dates are used to work out which projects are active or ended or planned for the future.
  • Active projects are projects with a start date in the past and with an end date in the future.
  • Ended projects are projects with an end date in the past.
  • Planned projects are anything with a start date in the future.
jpn.faq_technical_a9_text: Using ‘location’ tags within the data to plot projects on the maps - either lat/long or point/pos, depending on which the publisher uses.

jpn.faq_technical_q17_text: For the country and sector graphs on the acitivity pages, why have your changed them into bars?
jpn.faq_technical_q18_text: Why are some graphs missing for some types of transactions on the acitivity pages?

news/2014-05-08-Development-Tracker-Arch._blog_post_body:
...or 'Why we chose to use ECMAScript'.

We've been working on a project to build a re-usable piece of code that can be easily hosted by anyone, anywhere and that will tell an interesting story using IATI data, under the working title; D-Portal https://github.com/devinit/D-Portal

We were asked to build a HTML5 serverless design that would be easy to deploy and configure, so it was inevitable that ECMAScript (i.e. Javascript) would have to be used browser side.

Languages are always a contentious issue among programmers and picking a language to use for a project is not only a matter of compromise but something that has to be decided on rather quickly or it becomes very hard to make any progress.

We soon discovered that we would also need to have a server side component, something that processes raw data and makes it available to the client in a more digestible format. This could be written in any language but we chose to use a node server. Primarily this allows the same code to be shared between server and client and reduces code dependencies.

On top of this we use a zero configuration database (SQLite) so there is no need to install, configure and maintain a complicated database server.

Even if you do not consider yourself an ECMAScript programmer the ubiquity of the language online means that you have almost certainly worked with it, maybe you even consider it your second language. It is quite simply the language of the web and although Node is still rather new, what it represents is an inevitable, unstoppable spread of the language onto the server.

  • ECMAScript is the technical name of JSscript or JavaScript.
  • KISS is the design principle behind all of these decisions.
  • Node is a webserver based on googles V8 ECMAScript engine.


Originally posted on http://iati.github.io/

news/2014-05-28-Current-plans._blog_post_body:
Following an initial period of development in the first quarter of 2014, and the launch at the Global Partnership meeting in April, d-portal is now entering a period of consolidation and consultation. During this 3-4 month period we are aiming to do the following...

  • Stabilise the code base
  • Enable easy adoption of the code for anyone to create and customise individual country d-portals
  • Allow the addition of other datasets as simply as possible
  • Develop full guidance for those adopting the code
  • Write up comprehensive documentation and methodology
  • Consult with potential users around the longer term direction for d-portal
  • Consider means of funding and sustaining support and updates for d-portal

This page will contain any updates to information, and announcements on d-portal over the coming months. If you would like to keep up to date with news on d-portal please subscribe to the Google group.

Get in touch...

If you have any queries about d-portal, any comments or suggestions please do contact us at support@iatistandard.org

news/2014-11-28-Bringing-IATI-data-life-._blog_post_body:
The generator is a new d-portal feature that allows users to select subsets of International Aid Transparency Initiative (IATI) information from the d-portal website and embed them into their own websites and blogs.

What is d-portal?

d-portal is a platform that makes all IATI data available and accessible for anyone to explore. We set it up with the aim of allowing people in developing countries to view IATI information from their own country’s perspective. Nearly 300 organisations currently publish data on their activities to the IATI registry - d-portal transforms this machine-readable data into information for humans to understand. It shows you all published IATI data from the point of view of a recipient country or a organisation, and gives you the chance to drill down to individual project detail. Users can see what data exists, who has published and who hasn’t yet, and where there are data quality issues.

What does the d-portal generator do?

There is a huge amount of interesting information within IATI (and therefore, d-portal) and significant value in being able to share bite-size pieces of it freely on other websites and blogs. The d-portal generator allows users to select specific information from d-portal and embed it directly into their own website code.

How do you use the generator?

There are lots of combinations and possibilities of what to choose when selecting from the vast amount of data in d-portal, so we tried to make the process as simple as possible…



1. Choose a combination of Organisation(s) & Recipient(s) information to view
2. Select how you want to display it (a map, table, list, pie chart, etc)
3. Select a colour scheme and re-size the width if required

Once you’ve completed steps 1 & 2 (3 is optional), you’ll see some code appear automatically in the white box, and an example of your selected content below that box (as below). You then just need to copy the code and paste it into the code of your website or blog post, to embed the content you’ve generated.



Here’s the live example of the content which we've chosen, and embedded into this page:

Once you’ve embedded any content it will update automatically (overnight) as organisations’ data is updated in the IATI registry. When users click on the content they will be directed to the relevant page on d-portal so they can investigate further.

We have used the tool to embed a simple table about our IATI data here. We have also created a page showing some more examples of what you can do with d-portal generator content here.

More about…

IATI data includes data from donor governments and multilaterals, NGOs, foundations and private sector companies. It is forward-looking (it contains 2015 data from many organisations), comparable and increasingly comprehensive.

Both the d-portal and the d-portal generator are currently in beta. We’d love to hear your feedback, so please let us know if you use either d-portal or the generator, and tell us about your experience; please send comments, queries and feedback to support@iatistandard.org, or raise issues on the d-portal GitHub.

If you are interested in finding out more or part-funding d-portal, please contact support@iatistandard.org

Links

Create IATI content with the d-portal Generator

news/2014-11-30-Interactive-IATI-data-d-._blog_post_body:
d-portal is a platform that makes all IATI data accessible, and is a useful tool for investigating the increasing amount of IATI data. Nearly 300 organisations publish their activities in the IATI registry, so we set up d-portal to turn that data into simple information for everyone – particularly those in developing countries interested in seeing information from their own country’s perspective. In addition to this, we recently added the generator - to provide a means of re-using the IATI data in d-portal, by embedding it into other websites and blog posts.

How to select and embed content

Here we give you some examples of information you can show using the d-portal generator - these are various randomly chosen examples of data which are currently published to IATI, but of course you can choose any current publisher, or combinations of publishers and recipients, depending on what information you want to display.

This is a snapshot of a simple query we've run on the generator...choosing Development Initiatives from the Publisher dropdown, and then the 'Sectors (table)' view...



...and here's the resulting table - which we've embedded below by copying the code generated in the white box (above), and pasting it into the html code for this webpage. You can now click on information in the table, to explore further...

By changing around what you select in the generator dropdowns you can create a variety of different content - here's a few more examples of content that we generated from the IATI data in d-portal. We'd love to hear your feedback from using d-portal and the generator - please do email us any thoughts and feedback.

See here for more information about DI's IATI data.

d-portal generator examples...

(Publisher) ActionAid International ~ (View) List of activities (5) ~ Mustard ~ 750 pixels

(Recipient) Angola ~ (View) Top Donors for a single recipient (graph) ~ High

(Publisher) The World Bank ~ (View) Map ~ 750 pixels

(Publishers) WaterAid, United Nations Childrens Fund, The Coca-Cola Export Corporation, Heifer International South Africa ~ (Recipient) Liberia ~ (View) Recipients (table) ~ 750 pixels

news/2015-11-05-Adding-country-budgets-t._blog_post_body:
We have made a small change to what information is shown in organisation tables in d-portal – the ones where you are looking from an individual organisation’s perspective at recipient countries – by including organisation file budgets. This is budget data which some organisations provide in their IATI organisation file (as opposed to activity files, where most other IATI data is reported) and it represents the total annual budget for that organisation, per recipient country.

So instead of seeing the 2015 and 2016 activity file budget columns in tables such as this, you can now see and compare the budgets related to existing activities (from the activity files – the column which we have called ‘allocated’) and the budget information in general for that country (the column which we have called ‘total’).

Note - you can still scroll through past/future years using the arrows at the top of the table.

The reason for this change is both to highlight the existence of general budget data within organisation files, which are potentially valuable data but not often known about or updated, and as a response to requests from users to be able to see this information – which (provided the data is up to date) allows you to start working out the remaining unallocated budget for a recipient country.

As always if you notice anything that you want to follow up on d-portal, have any questions or suggestions please do get in touch...

Following requests from users about showing Results data in IATI with in d-portal you can now see this on the individual activity (SAVi) pages – if you drill down into the data through the chart and tables, or via the maps, to see an individual activity you should be able to scroll down past the details of individual transactions within that activity and see information on Results (as long as the organisation has reported Results data in their xml!).

For example on this SAVi page for a Cordaid activity on improving health care in Zimbabwe you can see the Results data that Cordaid have published for this activity...

news/2016-06-17-The-Generator-how-to-get._blog_post_body:
Check out this excellent vimeo that Bond put together which shows you the quick and simple steps to using the d-portal generator.

The generator allows you to choose from a wide variety of ways to view IATI data within d-portal, and then provides a link for you to easily embed the content you’ve chosen into your own site – great if you want to display your own IATI data in an engaging way, or are looking to visualise other IATI data for analysis. You can embed charts, tables, maps and various other content, all of which can then be clicked through to allow users to explore the data further in d-portal – and once it’s embedded in your site it will update automatically overnight!

Feedback welcome as always – on the generator or other areas of d-portal...

news/2017-06-12-Finding-context-in-Resul._blog_post_body:
Results data heirarchy is not particularly verbose.


Fig. 1 The results element heirarchy

At its most basic, there is a title, description and an indicator. The indicator makes up most of the results element with links to reference documents, a baseline and the all important period element. Here in the period element will contain the start and end dates, target and actual values and within those, location and dimensions data like sex, gender and age. Dimensions data is freetext so there are no restrictions to what a organisation can well, publish. Due to this, data within this element might be difficult to aggregate.

There are also multiple narrative and comment elements within the results subelements. We found that organisations tend to repeat themselves rather than add new information in these sections.

SAVi displays complex-looking IATI XML (the elements found in a single activity) in a format that is hopefully, easier to read and digest. To achieve this, we try to understand the context of the data being used and how best to lay it out so that it makes the most sense to the casual user. Thus far, we're only showing the most commonly used elements of the IATI schema, which means there are still parts of the XML hidden from view on SAVi pages. This doesn't mean we've changed the original XML in any shape or form (you still have access to this via the xml link on each SAVi page) but it does mean there are still many parts of the iati-activity element that we've not fully understood or explored. Hopefully, as more elements get adopted by organisations, we'll get the opportunity to delve deeper into use cases that are in demand.

When we were first asked to display results data in SAVi, we misunderstood it entirely! Without context or how and what it was used for, a structure to compose a visual layout was at most, based on assumptions.


Fig. 2 First iteration of results data saw a rudimentary layout without baseline data

The first thing we had to do was find some actual results data to work with. Preferably an activity with most of the results subelement completed; this seemed a harder feat than we thought.

I visited the IATI Dashboard to point me in the right direction. The dashboard has been really useful in terms of finding organisations using certain elements, especially so for SAVi as we're always trying to visualise certain sections of an activity and this always meant looking for example data. The only thing I wish the dashboard would do was display the full organisation name or even their reporting-org id instead of their IATI Registry id as that would not only save me one more step (currently, I have to click on the organisation link to find out the actual organisation name) but it would be consistent with other parts of the dashboard website where the full organisation names are displayed.

In any case, there was still a lot to do after this to find an activity that has a high completion of the result subelements. This prompted us to add a new query parameter to Q which is live right now on d-portal. Give it a go!

http://d-portal.org/q.json?from=element&orderby=element_volume-&limit=10&element_name0=result

The above query will display the top 10 activities that contain the 'result' element in descending order of frequency as JSON. Replace .json with .html, .xml or .csv if you prefer.

The query is 4 levels deep, this is enough to reach the deepest part of the IATI standard. For example, if I want to search for activities that have dimension data within the target element of results data, my query will look like this:

http://d-portal.org/q.json?from=element&orderby=element_volume-&limit=10&element_name0=dimension&element_name1=target&element_name2=period&element_name3=indicator

As you can see, the query starts with the innermost element and you'll need to list the hierarchy as it appears in the standard.

We started going down the route of deeper searches into attributes but this is a rather resource hungry option so we've taken it out for now. If there are demands for such things in the future, do let us know.

During the four-day Open Ag Tool workshop, we met experts in the field who gave us guidance on approaching results data. Nadeja Mandrescu from Development Gateway not only shared how results data was published and how baseline was calculated, she also explained how different organisations had different approaches to publishing this data - Yearly, Quarterly etc. This gave us some context and a brief overview of the rather complex nature of the results data element.

*Fig. 3 WIP iteration of results data with two columns made the baseline look out of place*

We were later approached by Andy Lulham from Publish What You Fund about the way we visualised baseline data (or rather, the lack of it)! He pointed out the importance of baseline data, how it provided context for the target and actual elements and how it would make better visual sense to include it alongside the two columns. This looked like it was getting somewhere close to making sense!

Looking closer, we agreed that baseline could be interpreted as the 'start' value where 'target' and 'actual' data is based on (hence, 'baseline').

Throughout the day, we huddled with so many exchanging findings. Nick Hamlin from Global Giving shared interesting observations when he applied machine learning to a results dataset we supplied him with. We both agreed that there is still the issue of what results actually mean to organisations and this interpretation affects the level of granularity being published. Reid Porter from InterAction shared at length the background of historical data and how things can get lost in translation when very complex multi-system architectures are used within organisations, to then derive standardised results data from these systems is a close to impossible feat. Taryn Davis from Development Gateway shared the need for visualisations and computing graphs from results data that could be viewed on an ag specific dashboard. We all agreed that numerical values in the target and actual elements were best to achieve aggregation than having text in there as well.

We prodded further and found that baseline years were usually in alignment with period-start years but also that at times, organisations were publishing more than one period within an indicator. In terms of hierarchy, baseline data sits outside the period element which means multiple periods share just the one baseline.

Visualising this as a three column layout will be tricky so we've duplicated the baseline element into each period element, after the period-start and period-end dates. This meant the 3 columns could be used to compare values within the period element and visually, that made sense.

*Fig. 4 Next iteration of results data with 3 columns for comparison*

We've attached further visual feedback to the actual elements; green if the actual value is equals to or more than the target value and off-yellow for actual values that are less than the target value. The actual box remains neutral blue if value data is missing or incorrect; ie. text is published instead of actual numbers.

We've also added a small indicator to show if the period data is still ongoing or has ended. This is represented by a 'progress bar' timeline underneath the period dates.

*Fig. 5 Current iteration of results data with fixed height and timeline bar*

You can view this particular example activity on d-portal here.

Results data with indicators and values are now live on d-portal and further iterations will continue as we get a better understanding of how to present the data for use.

Many thanks to the organisers of the workshop and everyone who came up to us to share knowledge, it was humbling and eye-opening to see so many dedicated people working together towards the same goal with so much enthusiasm. We look forward to following the progress of all the resulting projects and outcomes of this workshop.

_blog_post_json.about: Updates from the Open Ag Tool workshop and an in-depth look at the element.
_blog_post_json.author: Shi
_blog_post_json.title: Finding context in Results data and new query parameter

news/2017-09-06-New-d-portal-search-feat._blog_post_body:
Exciting news for data users - we’ve added some great new search features to IATI’s platform d-portal.org.

The changes (part-funded by Interaction) mean that searches for IATI data on aid, development and humanitarian activities are easier and can be more refined.

You said, we did...

We’re grateful to our keen d-portal users for providing useful feedback on what needs to be improved. So here’s what has changed:

1. Choose multiple options
Now you can choose more than one option in every category, allowing you to find data for multiple recipient countries, publishers and/or sectors.

Here we’re using this new feature to search for spending and activities across three sectors relating to health in Liberia.


Fig. 1 Multiple options in a single dropdown

2. Search by activity status
Want to look at what activities are being planned for the future, or see what’s already been implemented? Now you can using our new activity status filter.


Fig. 2 New activity status dropdown

3. Free text activity search
Want to find a specific activity? Now there’s no need to look through many search results, just simply cut and paste the activity ID number in the free text box and you’ll be taken straight to that activity’s page.

By searching 41119-AF-OTHER-S10-NGO here


Fig. 3 Type in an activity id and press enter

you’ll be taken to the United Nations Population Fund’s activity in Afghanistan on preventing gender-based violence.


Fig. 4 The SAVi page for that activity

Other important changes
Following requests, users now have the option to order dropdowns alphabetically or by IATI code and FAQs on the search functions have been added here too.

Can we expect more changes to d-portal? IATI is continually working on more ways to ensure people can access the data they want through d-portal. Please share any comments or suggestions via GitHub or email support@iatistandard.org.

_blog_post_json.about: An in-depth look at the new features and how to use them as data users.
_blog_post_json.author: Matt Bartlett
_blog_post_json.title: New d-portal search features to improve data use

news/2017-09-06-New-d-portal-search-feat.title: {_blog_post_json.title}

news/2018-03-20-Server-upgrade-and-other._blog_post_body:
To support the growing database, we have had to make some significant changes to the way d-portal imports data from the IATI Registry with the first move being a new server that has a larger capacity and faster speed to accommodate the current and potential future size. The old server was also dangerously close to being out of storage space which resulted in a slow response time when you browsed through the website.

With increased capacity, the new server performs a full import considerably faster than it used to; just 3 hours instead of 3 whole days. This is made possible with support for parallel importing - instead of importing 1 activity per second, we are now able to import over 100 activities per second.

Result data

Figure 1. Updated display of result data with support for 2.03 on SAVi

With the new version 2.03 upgrade, there has been some considerable updates to the result element in the standard. This means the current method of displaying result data also needs updating. Many thanks to this Github issue, we were able to accommodate those changes to better support the new version.

Dataset logs

Figure 2. Dedicated dataset logs on Dash screenshot

There is now a link to the d-portal logs of each dataset on the SAVi pages of each activity. A dataset is a valid XML file imported from a organisation's server that contains a number of activities. You can view this particular one here.

Figure 3. A daily log of 1 imported dataset from the registry

Clicking through the dataset log link will direct you to a page where you are able to check for any problems that may have arose during the last import. These imports are done nightly so we have the latest data on d-portal. Problems may include download or import errors and duplicate activity identifiers, which are quite common and can easily cause missing data on d-portal.

Dash

Figure 4. Link to full list of imported datasets

There is now a link to view all the imported datasets and their logs on the front page of Dash. Dash is an overview of the data populating d-portal. We use it primarily to double-check instances where d-portal isn't displaying information as expected.

Figure 5. List of all imported datasets with links to IATI Registry and dataset logs

Clicking through the link will direct you to the full list of all datasets that have been imported from IATI Registry. This list allows us convenient access to links and logs to track down problems with the imported data.

Let’s take a look at a few of these problems in the examples below.

Figure 6. An example dataset that could not be downloaded

You can easily see what went wrong in this example - we were unable to download the dataset from the source server (the requested URL returned error: 404 Not Found). This means the data will not be imported into the d-portal database and so will be missing from the website.

Figure 7. An example dataset that did not import

This dataset downloaded fine from the source server but it faced problems during the step where we import it into the database. By visiting the url at the top of the logs, we are able to find out why. In this case, the downloaded dataset was not an XML file.

Figure 8. An example dataset failed download but imported fine

This dataset was not available from the organisation server but we had a cached version on our server so we were able to import the cached version into the database for display.

For such cases, we assume this is an intermittent error which will be fixed shortly by the organisation. In the meantime, we will use any cached files to populate d-portal.

Cron logs

Figure 8. Link to the nightly cron logs

Logs of nightly imports can be viewed on the front page of Dash. The time stamp shows the last time the nightly script was run.

Figure 10. Errors now link to the specific logs

We’ve added a small update to how messages are displayed here. Errors found in the cron logs now link to specific database logs for easy access. This makes the process of checking individual links to error messages much more efficient.

This concludes some of the more recent technical updates for d-portal. If you'd like to know more, do join in the discussion on GitHub. We look forward to hearing from you.

_blog_post_json.about: We take a good look at the new features in Dash as well as the new improved server.
_blog_post_json.author: Shi
_blog_post_json.title: Server upgrade and other updates

news/2018-03-21-Reaching-over-1-million-._blog_post_body:
Figure 1. Over a million activities published on d-portal

D-portal has reached over a million activities in the database.

Figure 2. Early January with 784540 activities

This is a huge difference when compared to 785,000 at the beginning of the year and we expect this number to increase as the months go by.

CSV map download

Figure 3. Twitter announcement of CSV download

We’ve added the ability for you to download csv data with coordinates (as well as other relevant fields).

Figure 4. Click on the 'View all' link to view more map data

This new feature can be found on the map views of individual country or organisation profiles by clicking on the link shown above.

Figure 5. Click on 'CSV' to start downloading data

This data can also be further filtered by using the dropdown; ie. choosing ‘Active’ will only download ‘Active’ activities.

IATI is continually working on more ways to ensure people can access the data they want through d-portal. Please share any comments or suggestions via GitHub or email support@iatistandard.org. With your help, we can make d-portal better.

news/2019-01-14-New-year-new-features-an._blog_post_body:
We've been quite busy at d-portal. There have been some considerable changes since the last news post, as well as minor cosmetic upgrades throughout the site, so here is a quick rundown of things added since December.

New features

Figure 1. New addition to the transaction table - groupings and graphs

Transactions are now grouped by type in SAVi (#379). This should make it easier to quickly look through the otherwise, unwieldy list. By doing this, we're able to add simple graphs for each transaction type.

The main graph will collectively display all transaction types reported within the activity and individual graphs will be displayed below each section.

Transactions are merged if they are published for the same date and we're only showing graphs for transactions that have been published using the same currency.

Figure 2. Country bar graph

We've replaced the Sector and Country pie charts with more useful bar graphs. The previous Google graphs are fully deprecated with some pages not showing them at all even when data is present.

Figure 3. Sector bar graph

It should now be easier to see the data in relation to percentages. We're also displaying the 2-digit country codes and sector codes.

Add Sectors to map csv download (#480)

Figure 4. Sector data in csv download

CSV data downloads now include both sectors and sector groups (DAC 5 and 3 Digit codes) as columns.

At present, the downloaded data does not reflect what you see on the map page so we are very keen to devote more time to creating a proper interface to access such data, but this will take some time. As such, it would be good to know if we should prioritise such a thing.

If you would like to see this developed, let us know here.

Display humanitarian in transactions (#501)

Figure 5. Humanitarian flag displayed on SAVi (Simple Activity Viewer)

For activities reported using iati-activity/@humanitarian, ie. the entire activity relates to humanitarian aid, we're displaying a humanitarian flag in the activity viewer.

Figure 6. Displaying humanitarian flag at transaction level

At transaction level, the flag is displayed within the transaction tables.

According to the standard, reporting @humanitarian at transaction level does not indicate that the entire activity is related to humanitarian aid. Therefore, the display here will differ.

Display 'Withdrawn' for withdrawn Sectors in search dropdown (#455)

Figure 7. Withdrawn codes in search dropdown (Image by Andy Lulham) and in sector graph

Withdrawn codes are now styled differently in the search dropdown to make it easier to differentiate them.

Withdrawn sector codes are also displayed accordingly in the new graphs.

Add and display ref attribute (#417)

Figure 8. Displaying organisation references

With the addition of displaying the @ref attribute, the participating-org list looks to be getting longer and longer. This is a first step in showing as much data as is published in an activity - we'll be looking at making this section more manageable in the near future.

Display organisation-type for provider and receiver (#475)

Figure 9. Displaying type and references at transaction level

Organisation type and references are useful information to see in the context of an activity. These attributes are now displayed at transaction and planned disbursement levels when they are reported.

Other additions, updates and fixes

  • Add humanitarian-scope and display in SAVi (#473)
  • Add and display activity-scope (#497)
  • Default graph to all years (#469)
  • Update FAQ (#441) We're always looking for translations - can you help?
  • Fixed text bug (#499)

Many thanks to those who have continually supported the development of d-portal by using and promoting the site. Special thanks to those who have given us feedback, requested features and reported bugs through Github - with your input, d-portal is continuously improving!

IATI is working on more ways to ensure people can access the data they want through d-portal. Please share any comments or suggestions via GitHub or email support@iatistandard.org. With your help, we can make d-portal better.

_blog_post_json.about: Upgrading the transaction tables in SAVi, replacing deprecated pie charts and displaying more elements in the activity viewer.
_blog_post_json.author: Shi
_blog_post_json.title: New year, new features and additions

news/2019-01-14-New-year-new-features-an.title: {_blog_post_json.title}

spa.about_paragraph10_text: DI está financiando la fase actual del desarrollo y la preparación hasta el final de agosto 2014 Si usted está interesado en la financiación de parte de la elaboración en curso de d- portal , por favor póngase en contacto con support@iatistandard.org
spa.about_paragraph11_text: El concepto de código abierto se basa en el intercambio de recursos con la esperanza de que otros se unan a adentro y construir una mejor plataforma juntos. Esto incluye la búsqueda y notificación de errores, aportando nuevas características que le gustaría tener la plataforma o incluso la creación de nuevos temas para que otros puedan utilizarlo.
spa.about_paragraph12_text: Otros sitios sobre la base de d-portal se enumeran a continuación. Contáctenos al support@iatistandard.org añadir el suyo aquí.
spa.about_paragraph14_text: 1. ¿De dónde provienen los recursos? 2. ¿A dónde van (por sector y ubicación)?
spa.about_paragraph15_text: Los datos recientes, actuales y futuros se presenta y comparado a través de fuentes de datos.
spa.about_paragraph1_text: d-portal.org le ayuda a explorar los datos de la IATI, proporcionando información por país o por el editor en las actividades de desarrollo y los presupuestos publicados hasta la IATI.
spa.about_paragraph2_text: Está dirigido a ofrecer a los ministerios de línea , los parlamentarios y la sociedad civil una información que le puede ayudar con la planificación y el seguimiento de las actividades de desarrollo .
spa.about_paragraph3_text: En su primera versión que contiene los datos actuales publicados a través de la Iniciativa Internacional de Transparencia de la Ayuda ( IATI ), así como los datos más recientes (2012) publicados por el OECD DAC Creditor Reporting System.
spa.about_paragraph4_text: La plataforma actual plantea dos preguntas:
spa.about_paragraph5_text: Con el fin de responder a estas preguntas desde una perspectiva nacional es insuficiente simplemente para mostrar los datos disponibles: es igualmente importante para trazar las lagunas en la información. Hacer frente a la mala calidad o los datos que faltan es una parte esencial de la interfaz de información.
spa.about_paragraph6_text: es una plataforma de código abierto. Esto significa que puede utilizar todos los aspectos de la plataforma para construir su propio portal utilizando el código fuente libre.
spa.about_paragraph7_text: A pesar de que actualmente proporciona una implementación genérica para cualquier país que se ha desarrollado con la intención específica de ser modificado para requisitos particulares en el país para satisfacer las necesidades locales. Para más información sobre cómo se puede crear una versión personalizada para un país específico, consulte Cómo instalar.
spa.about_paragraph9_text: El desarrollo inicial de d- portal.org que duró desde diciembre de 2013 hasta la reunión de la Alianza Global en México en abril de 2014 fue financiada por IATI y Development Initiatives (DI).
spa.alert1_text: d-portal.org está todavía en desarrollo muy temprano, programado para su estreno a mediados de abril Alfa. Gracias por su paciente usted! Lamentablemente Cualquier comentario
spa.back_news_text: Volver a la página de Noticias
spa.dash_paragraph1_text: Dash es un resumen de los datos que pueblan d-portal.org con un enfoque principalmente en estadísticas para afiliados y la calidad de los datos notificados por ellos.
spa.dash_paragraph2_text: Al mostrar cuándo y dónde se informa de datos no válidos, Dash será capaz de explicar las diferencias que se reflejan en el sitio principal.
spa.dash_paragraph3_text: Dash no es específico de cada país por lo que será capaz de ver todas las estadísticas para afiliados disponibles en todos los países incluidos en el portal. Esto es para acomodar el hecho de que hay varios editores que reportan actividades en varios países receptores.
spa.dash_paragraph4_text: Dash es actualmente accesible en http://d-portal.org/ctrack.html?#view=dash. Dash es una característica nueva y todavía se está desarrollando.
spa.discover_paragraph1_text: Explore es una nueva característica que se encuentra actualmente en fase de desarrollo pesada. Con el respaldo de dStore y Q, que proporcionará una sencilla interfaz de búsqueda de los usuarios filtrar a través de la amplia base de datos de la IATI.
spa.discover_paragraph2_text: Actualmente estamos buscando comentarios sobre la intuición y la facilidad de uso de Explore. No tener un ir y nos envíe sus comentarios mediante la adición de una nueva emisión a través de la Github foro o, si lo prefiere, ponerse en contacto a través de support@iatistandard.org. Nos encantaría saber lo que piensas!
spa.dlogs_paragraph1_text: Estadísticas y gráficos de la base de datos de d-portal generados por las importaciones nocturnas. Esto fue creado para rastrear el creciente número de actividades de IATI publicadas en d-portal.
spa.dlogs_paragraph2_text: Visite la base de datos en https://xriss.github.io/D-Portal-Logs/
spa.dlogs_title_text: Registros de la base de datos
spa.dquery_paragraph1_text: Como interfaz SQL de solo lectura para la base de datos completa, dquery proporciona a los usuarios técnicos acceso a todos los datos del portal D de IATI y opciones para descargar los datos en formatos XML, JSON, HTML y CSV.
spa.dquery_paragraph2_text: Esta nueva característica aún se está probando y actualizando. Póngase en contacto si tiene alguna pregunta o sugerencia.
spa.dstore_paragraph_text: dstore subvenciona la IATI Registry con una versión nodejs + PostgreSQL + SQLite optimizado para su uso en las consultas en tiempo real.
spa.explore_paragraph1_text: Escoge un país o editor de abajo para explorar sus datos.
spa.explore_paragraph2_text: Sólo los países y editores con los datos publicados a IATI están disponibles para la exploración.
spa.faq_explore_a1_text:
EXPLORE is made up of two parts – a series of filters, and a freetext box.

1. Filters

These are a selection of filters relating to the IATI Standard allowing users to choose and refine the IATI data they want to explore.

2. Freetext

This is a freetext box allowing users to search for themes and topics, and specific activities published to IATI.
spa.faq_explore_a2_text: The EXPLORE feature is on the front page of d-portal.org and helps users find activities published to the IATI Standard based on keywords - it was originally developed to help people who wanted to find information on specific humanitarian crises.
spa.faq_explore_a3_text:
Select multiple filters from across the dropdowns. As you build a query using these filters the space underneath the filters will populate with an indication of how many activities are available to view based on your selections.

You can then click ‘Explore Results’ to find out more about those activities.
spa.faq_explore_a4_text:
Recipient Country and Publisher

The organisations that have published to the IATI Standard, and the countries where funds have gone to as published within IATI data.

Sector Group and Sector

The numeric codes and names to describe sectors within the OECD DAC CRS, as used within the IATI Standard.

Activity Status

The numeric codes and names within the IATI activity status field.

Year Range

Years from 1960 to ‘present year + 2’.

More filters

The numeric codes and names within the IATI activity status field. Click on Glossary to find out more about individual filters.
spa.faq_explore_a5_text:
Type in one or more keywords and press enter to see how many activities have been found.

Click ‘Explore Results’ to see lists, graphs and maps allowing further exploration of the data.

Refine your search by adding multiple words – e.g. ‘Hurricane Matthew’ will find more refined (fewer) results than ‘Hurricane’.
spa.faq_explore_a6_text: Clicking ‘Explore Results’ provides results in the usual d-portal format (stats and charts which you can explore by clicking through to tables).
spa.faq_explore_a7_text: This searches the Title and Description fields within all published IATI activities.
spa.faq_explore_a8_text: EXPLORE is adapted for English plural nouns - e.g. typing ‘Refugee’ will include results for ‘Refugees’.
spa.faq_explore_a9_text: The COVID-19 button follows the IATI Publishing Guidance. It currently searches the database for COVID-19 in title and description fields and looks for the relevant codes in the humanitarian-scope element.
spa.faq_explore_q3_text: How can I use the filters?
spa.faq_explore_q4_text: What is the data in the dropdown lists within filters?
spa.faq_explore_q5_text: How can I use and refine the freetext search?
spa.faq_explore_q6_text: How / what do the EXPLORE search results show?
spa.faq_explore_q7_text: When doing a freetext search, what IATI fields are being searched?
spa.faq_explore_q8_text: Do plural nouns work in freetext search?
spa.faq_explore_q9_text: How does the Trending buttons work?
spa.faq_general_a10_text: Either on our GitHub issues page or via support@iatistandard.org
spa.faq_general_a11_text: See milestones on GitHub issues page or contact us at support@iatistandard.org
spa.faq_general_a12_text:
See the About page.

Look at the issues on GitHub.

Contact us - support@iatistandard.org
spa.faq_general_a13_text:
Data that is marked as invalid IATI xml when using the Validator.

Mismatch between ‘Identifier’ in publisher’s profile in the IATI Registry, and reporting-org in that publisher’s data – this will show zeroes in the publisher’s data until the two are matched.

Transaction type code not present.

Not using either Disbursements or Expenditure in transaction type field.

Country and Sector graphs are displayed by adding up Transaction type codes 3 (Disbursement) and 4 (Expenditure) so activities without transactions or the right transaction type codes will not have these graphs.

Dates in incorrect format in the data.

Activities without end date are not shown on the list of projects ending soon or any lists that need an end date to order them.

The map section will not be shown if there are no activities with longitude and latitude data.

Illogical dates such as activity end date before activity start date.

No data relevant to the year being viewed on a pie chart or table (eg where a pie chart shows 2024 data and data published only relates to 2023).

If updating your Registry profile only, changes will show after the weekly full import (each weekend) as d-portal only updates nightly the data that has been changed in the xml.
spa.faq_general_a1_text: A view of all IATI (International Aid Transparency Initiative) data by recipient country or publisher, comparable with latest OECD DAC CRS (Creditor Reporting System) data.
spa.faq_general_a2_text: IATI and CRS data (see below for more information).
spa.faq_general_a3_text: The International Aid Transparency Initiative - IATI is a voluntary, multi-stakeholder initiative that seeks to improve the transparency of aid, development, and humanitarian resources in order to increase their effectiveness in tackling poverty.
spa.faq_general_a4_text: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development’s Development Assistance Committee Creditor Reporting System - which contains Official Development Assistance data.
spa.faq_general_a5_text:
The IATI data comes from the IATI Registry.

The CRS data comes from CRS tables and stored on Github.
spa.faq_general_a6_text:
Publishers report their IATI data at varying degrees of detail, and data is updated and improved all the time by publishers. If a publisher only publishes data for 2023, it won’t appear in 2024 columns/charts etc.

d-portal attempts to only reflect what is in the data and does not make corrections to data or information published to IATI, with only small exceptions to make the site user-friendly*

See also information about data quality (Afghanistan used as example)
spa.faq_general_a7_text:
Zeroes may denote issues with data quality (eg codes, dates, etc which are incompatible with the IATI Standard). There will shortly be links to the publisher’s page on the IATI dashboard to investigate specific data quality issues.

Dashes show that that donor/organisation is not currently an IATI publisher.
spa.faq_general_a8_text:
IATI data is updated every night (importing any data which has changed from the previous day) and a full import is done each weekend - in each instance the data is pulled from the IATI Registry.

CRS data is downloaded annually when it becomes available and then stored in Github.
